text: is an old province of Japan in the area of Yamagata Prefecture on the island of Honshū.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "Uzen" in Japan Encyclopedia, p. 1019. Along with Ugo Province, it was sometimes called .Murdoch, James. (1903). A History of Japan, Vol. 3. p. 794. The history of the province started in 1868 and ended in 1872. ==History== During the Edo period and early Meiji period, the Uesugi clan were daimyo in the area.Papinot, Edmund. (2003). Nobiliare du Japon -- Uesugi, pp. 67 [PDF 71 of 80;] Papinot, Jacques Edmond Joseph. (1906). Dictionnaire d’histoire et de géographie du Japon; retrieved 2012-11-8. Copper coins were minted in the province in 1861-1863 (Bunkyu 1-3).Van de Polder, Léon. (1891). "Abridged History of the Copper Coins of Japan," Transactions of the Asiatic Society of Japan, Vol. 18-19, p. 490. In the Meiji period, the provinces of Japan were converted into prefectures. Maps of Japan and Unzen Province were reformed in the 1870s.Nussbaum, "Provinces and prefectures" at p. 780. ==Related pages== * Provinces of Japan * Prefectures of Japan * List of regions of Japan * List of islands of Japan ==Notes== ==Other websites == * Murdoch's map of provinces, 1903 Category:Former provinces of Japan Category:Yamagata Prefecture
